# _Le bonheur de vivre_

From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia

Jump to: navigation, search

For other uses, see [Joy of life](/wiki/Joy_of_life_\(disambiguation\) "Joy of
life \(disambiguation\)").

Le bonheur de vivre  
---  
[![Bonheur
Matisse.jpg](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/b/b9/Bonheur_Matisse.jpg/300px-
Bonheur_Matisse.jpg)](/wiki/File:Bonheur_Matisse.jpg)  
Artist | [Henri Matisse](/wiki/Henri_Matisse "Henri Matisse")  
Year | Between October 1905 and March 1906  
Medium | Oil on canvas  
Dimensions | 176.5 cm × 240.7 cm (69.5 in × 94.75 in)  
Location | [Barnes Foundation](/wiki/Barnes_Foundation "Barnes Foundation"), Philadelphia, Pennsylvania  
  
_**Le bonheur de vivre**_ (_The Joy of Life_) is a painting by [Henri
Matisse](/wiki/Henri_Matisse "Henri Matisse"). Along with
[Picasso](/wiki/Picasso "Picasso")'s _[Les Demoiselles
d'Avignon](/wiki/Les_Demoiselles_d%27Avignon "Les Demoiselles d'Avignon")_,
_Le bonheur de vivre_ is regarded as one of the pillars of early
[modernism](/wiki/Modernism "Modernism").[1] The monumental canvas was first
exhibited at the [Salon des Indépendants](/wiki/Salon_des_Ind%C3%A9pendants
"Salon des Indépendants") of 1906, where its cadmium colors and spatial
distortions caused a public expression of protest and outrage.[1]

##
Description[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Le_bonheur_de_vivre&action=edit&section=1
"Edit section: Description")]

In the central background of the piece is a group of figures that is similar
to the group depicted in his painting _[The
Dance](/wiki/The_Dance_\(second_version\) "The Dance \(second version\)")_
(1909–10). In the picture, there are several nude bodies of women and men in a
landscape drenched with vivid color.

##
Inspiration[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Le_bonheur_de_vivre&action=edit&section=2
"Edit section: Inspiration")]

"The work is known to have invigorated fellow artists, especially [Pablo
Picasso](/wiki/Pablo_Picasso "Pablo Picasso"), who, in an effort to outdo
Matisse in terms of shock value, immediately began work on his watershed _Les
Demoiselles D’Avignon_ ", writes Martha Lucy, associate curator at the Barnes
Foundation.[1]

James B. Cuno and Thomas Puttfarken suggest that the inspiration for the work
was [Agostino Carracci](/wiki/Agostino_Carracci "Agostino Carracci")'s
engraving of [_Reciproco Amore_ or _Love in the Golden
Age_](/wiki/File:Agostino_Carracci_-
_Reciproco_Amore_or_Love_in_the_Golden_Age.jpg "File:Agostino Carracci -
Reciproco Amore or Love in the Golden Age.jpg") after the [similarly named
painting](/wiki/File:Pauwels_Franck_-_%22Amori%22-_Reciproco_amore_\(Et%C3%A1_dell%27oro\).jpg
"File:Pauwels Franck - "Amori"- Reciproco amore \(Etá dell'oro\).jpg") by the
16th-century Flemish painter [Paolo Fiammingo](/wiki/Paolo_Fiammingo "Paolo
Fiammingo"). Based on the many similarities with the engraving, in particular
its theme of pastoral fantasy and its composition with the circle of dancers
in the background, Cuno came to the conclusion that Carracci's engraving had a
decisive influence on the final composition of _Le Bonheur de Vivre_.[2][3][4]

According to [Hilton Kramer](/wiki/Hilton_Kramer "Hilton Kramer") _Le bonheur
de vivre_ , owing to its long sequestration in the collection of the [Barnes
Foundation](/wiki/Barnes_Foundation "Barnes Foundation") which never permitted
its reproduction in color, is the least familiar of modern masterpieces. Yet
this painting was Matisse's own response to the hostility his work had met
with in the [Salon d'Automne](/wiki/Salon_d%27Automne "Salon d'Automne") of
1905, a response that entrenched his art even more deeply in the esthetic
principles that had governed his [Fauvist](/wiki/Fauvist "Fauvist") paintings
which had caused a furor and which did so on a far grander scale, too."[5]
(The "sequestration" Kramer referred to relates to the very limited hours of
the museum, when its collection was located in suburban [Merion](/wiki/Merion
"Merion"), [Pennsylvania](/wiki/Pennsylvania "Pennsylvania"); in 2012, the
collection was moved to a new, more accessible facility in downtown
[Philadelphia](/wiki/Philadelphia "Philadelphia").)

##
Conservation[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Le_bonheur_de_vivre&action=edit&section=3
"Edit section: Conservation")]

_Le bonheur de vivre_ features a large amount of cadmium sulfide-based yellow.
Portions of the painting containing cadmium sulfide are turning white or
brown, degrading the work. [University of
Delaware](/wiki/University_of_Delaware "University of Delaware") Prof. Robert
L. Opila, in collaboration with Barbara Buckley, head of conservation at the
Barnes, and Jennifer Mass, a senior scientist and head of the Scientific
Research and Analysis Laboratory at Winterthur, studied the paint’s material
microstructure in an attempt to determine why the cadmium sulfide is changing
color.[1][6]

“It is a very disheartening phenomenon, considering the painting’s position in
history,” says Opila, professor of materials science at UD.[1][6]

Preliminary tests carried out by UD doctoral student Jonathan Church at the
European Synchrotron Radiation Facility (ESRF) in Grenoble, France, show that
carbon dioxide is reacting with the cadmium sulfide, causing the formation of
cadmium carbonate, which is white. Also, the presence of chloride in the paint
appears to be acting as a catalyst for the deterioration. Opila and his
research team theorize that the binder, an oil similar to linseed oil, may be
turning brown.[1][6]

“The scientific studies being undertaken will contribute significantly to the
preservation of the painting and to our understanding of the change that has
taken place to the visual appearance of the painting,” says Buckley.[1][6]
